newsitem.title: SWITZERLAND: Ex-Deutsche CEO says relaxed over German gold plan.
newsitem.headline: Ex-Deutsche CEO says relaxed over German gold plan.

text.p: Hilmar Kopper, former chief executive of Deutsche Bank AG and now its supervisory board chairman, said on Monday he was relaxed by Bonn's controversial plan to revalue Bundesbank gold reserves.

Speaking on the sidelines of the International Monetary Conference in Interlaken, Koppper said the timing of the revaluation plan might require more discussion but the project was not in itself a concern.
"I take a relaxed view on this," Kopper said. "One might argue over the timetable. But this is more a media issue than a real issue."
The Bundesbank has rejected a plan put forward by German Finance Minister Theo Waigel to revalue central bank gold and currency reserves to market prices.
It has argued that it would damage the central bank's independence and undermine the credibility of Germany's efforts to meet the criteria for European Econimic and Monetary Union (EMU).
Waigel has said he might receive a transfer from Bundesbank profits this year as result of this procedure, easing Germany's debt position in 1997.
